urn:contentItem:5XJT-MDR1-F03R-N05F-00000-00Google, Facebook, Amazon and Co are NOT offering banking, so stop saying they are2019-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:19ZLexisNexisGoogle, Facebook, Amazon and Co are NOT offering banking, so stop saying they areChris M Skinner

Nov 19, 2019( The Finanser by Chris Skinner: http://thefinanser.com/ Delivered by Newstex) In the last month, there's been a wave of announcements from Facebook, Apple, Google and Amazon about banking. We've seen Facebook's major activities in trying to create a digital currency called Libra, and Apple's move into finance with a credit card from Goldman Sachs which, in just a month, offered a $10 billion line of credit. Then, last week, Google partnered with Citi to offer a deposit account, as has Amazon and JPMorgan Chase. The result is a media frenzy of coverage, talking about the big move of Big Tech into banking.

My own take on this I've posted several times, most recently saying that Big Tech can only get into banking with Big Banks. Big Banks AND Big Tech (not versus)[1] So, why am I writing about this yet again? I'm writing about this yet again because most media coverage is completely getting this wrong. They're saying banks are dead meat and tech is taking over. Maybe the most interesting example of this is The Financial Times. In an article by Robert Armstrong[2], he states: Fundamentally, a bank is a balance sheet, a data-processing system and a sales force. Silicon Valley companies may be content to leave the balance sheet, the most heavily regulated bit, to the banks. But they are coming for the other parts. If banks such as Citi — which can trace its roots to 1812 — are seeking to do deals with them, you can expect plenty more to follow. Robert has got this right. Big Banks are highly capitalised and offer secure infrastructure for financial transaction processing. As I've written many, many, many times (read my books), banks are a combination of a manufacturer (balance sheet), infrastructure (data processing) and retailing (sales). When banks grow up, they will work out that they need to choose to focus upon their business models and which of these areas is of most import. And some banks are growing up. JPMC, Citi and Goldman are all choosing to be manufacturers and processors to the Big Tech giants. However, this does not mean it is at the cost of their retailing operations. It is a choice to add volume to their networks and make these partnerships before someone else does. We've seen this before. Twenty years ago, RBS did a deal with Tesco to run their back-end banking operations. Eventually, Tesco opened a full-service bank and left that deal. Has Tesco decimated RBS? No. But RBS said back at the time that it was all about getting more volume. Again, as Robert points out, Wal*Mart tried the same market grab. This phenomenon is not new: 20 years ago, Walmart tried to get into the retail banking business. After 10 years of trying, and waves of regulatory and political uproar, the retailer raised a white flag. What is key here is the regulatory and political uproar. Regulators will not allow Big Tech to take over Big Banking. They would worry too much about risk and data abuse. As a result, as I've said often, the likes of Facebook and Co will not succeed in getting into Big Banking. They will be blocked. Even if they tried, they would find the regulatory burden too much. The average bank has five times more regulatory oversight than the average technology firm. Why would you want five times more breathing down your neck? Equally, a lightly regulated market is sprightly and fast and innovative; a heavily regulated market is big and slow and risk averse. The two are at opposites, so why would the Big Tech want to get into Big Banking when it means they're going to be given handcuffs and shackles to be slow to change? No. It is far better to do this in partnership with banks, not at opposites with banks, especially when banks are your best customers. Amazon's AWS gets a huge amount of business from banks; Google gets a huge amount of revenue from bank advertising, as does Facebook. The bank as a customer means you don't want to be a bank's competitor. Even if you did want to compete, it's incredibly hard as the regulatory overhead is too high. That's what Tesco, Wal*Mart and others have discovered, and it's what Google, Facebook and Amazon are discovering. Therefore, when you look at Robert's last assertion, I think it is wrong. For many years, when asked whether big tech was a competitive threat, bank executives said that ultimately Google, Apple, Facebook and Amazon would not want to get involved in a capital-intensive, hyper-regulated industry such as finance. As time passes this sounds less like a coherent argument and more like an expression of hope. I disagree with that line, because they haven't got involved in a capital-intensive, hyper-regulated industry such as finance. Rather, they've found a capital-intensive, hyper-regulated financial partner to help them offer finance. That's a very different position. Finally, all of these reports of Google, Apple and Amazon getting into banking are false. Google is offering[3] the ability for users to 'access their bank accounts through the Google Pay app' and 'other banks could join up later' 'this is more about Google Pay and how they plan to position that going forward to access all financial products, not just credit cards'. It's not a bank account and anything like full-service banking which, when it is, is owned by a bank. Apple are offering[4] finance from Goldman Sachs under a white label agreement, and all the banking services and financial operations are managed by Goldman Sachs. It's not a bank account and anything like full-service banking which, when it is, is owned by Goldman Sachs. Amazon are now able[5] to use a JPMorgan e-wallet that could 'help them defend against getting cut out of the (gig economy) businesses they helped create'. It's not a bank account and anything like full-service banking which, when it is, is owned by JP Morgan Chase. So puh-lease will media stop saying that Big Tech is getting into banking. They're not. Big Tech are getting into partnerships with Big Banks and, even then, to offer a little more financial ease and not bank accounts. It's almost like Open Banking for the Americans. That's as far as it goes, end of. Posted on: November 19, 2019 [ 1]: https://thefinanser.com/2019/11/big-banks-and-big-tech-not-versus.html/ [ 2]:   https://www.ft.com/content/ac22c4de-078b-11ea-a984-fbbacad9e7dd [ 3]:   https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-11-13/google-partners-with-citi-to-offer-customers-checking-accounts [ 4]:   https://thefinanser.com/2019/03/everything-need-know-apples-new-credit-card-bit.html/ [ 5]:   https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-11-06/jpmorgan-has-a-plan-to-help-amazon-airbnb-look-more-like-banks

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60GG-C6Y1-DY1R-B3DS-00000-00Google, Facebook, Amazon, apple deny monopoly allegations to U.S. Congress.2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:19ZLexisNexisGoogle, Facebook, Amazon, apple deny monopoly allegations to U.S. Congress.


The CEOs of tech giants Google, Amazon, Apple and Facebook rejected on Wednesday - at a hearing in the U.S. House of Representatives - the accusations of dominant position and monopoly of the Democratic bench and the censorship criticism that unanimously came from Republicans.


The juiciest thing from the audience that sat Facebook, Apple, Amazon and Google on the bench [?? Subscribers only]
Despite the pharaonic size of these companies and their presence in various sectors of the new digital economy, Jeff Bezos (Amazon), Sundar Pichai (Google/Alphabet), Tim Cook (Apple) and Mark Zuckerberg (Facebook) painted a picture in which their companies not only do not operate in a monopoly, but are at risk of losing ground to their competitors or failing to offer services that they believe revitalize small businesses and create quality employment.
The four companies together annually enter about $800 billion, nearly three times the gross domestic product (GDP) of an emerging country such as Colombia, and have a market capitalization of $4.7 trillion, larger than the size of the German economy.
The Facebook leader, before the Congressional Commission. (AP)
The CEOs of four leading technology technologyists rejected accusations that their companies suffocate competition. A House committee is concluding its one-year investigation into market dominance in the sector.
Reports
Managers provided information to show how competitive their markets are, and the value of their innovation and essential services for consumers. However, they sometimes had trouble answering incisive questions about their business practices. They also had to confront various concerns about alleged political bias, its consequences on American democracy, and its role in China.
The four CEOs testified remotely to lawmakers, most of whom were seated, in masks, inside the courtroom in Washington.
Among the toughest questions for Google and Amazon were accusations that they used their dominant platforms to compile competitor data in a way that gave them an unfair advantage.
Bezos said in his first testimony to Congress that he could not guarantee that the company had not accessed information from vendors to manufacture competitive products, an accusation that the company and its executives have rejected earlier.
Regulators in the United States and Europe have scrutinized Amazon's relationship with companies that sell on its website and whether the online commerce giant has used vendor information to create its own-branded products.
Amazon's leader. (AP)
"We have a policy of not using vendor-specific information to help our private label business," Bezos said in response to a question from Democratic Rep. Pramila Jayapal.
"However, I cannot guarantee you that this policy was not violated.'"
In his opening statements, Pichai highlighted Google's value to family business in Bristol, Rhode Island, and Pewaukee, Wisconsin, in the residency districts of the president of the antitrust commission, Democratic Rep. David Cicilline of Rhode Island, and Republican James Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin.
However, the Google executive struggled when Cicilline accused the company of leveraging its dominant search engine to steal ideas and information from other websites and manipulate their results to lead users to their owndigital services to increase their profits.
Pichai repeatedly rejected Cicilline's attacks and noted that Google is trying to provide the most useful and relevant information to hundreds of millions of people who use its search engine every day in an attempt to get them back instead of going to a rival service, such as Microsoft's Bing.
While Democrats focused primarily on market competition, several Republicans voiced long-standing complaints that tech companies are censoring conservative voices, and questioned their business activities in China.
"Big tech companies go for conservatives," Rep. Jim Jordan said.
In a tweet before the hearing, President Donald Trump challenged Congress to take action against companies, which he has accused, without presenting evidence, of prejudice against him and conservatives in general.

urn:contentItem:5WJF-YVW1-DYRJ-03P2-00000-00Google, Facebook, Amazon, Apple to Testify at House Judiciary Subcommittee2019-07-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:19ZLexisNexisCAPITOL HILLGoogle, Facebook, Amazon, Apple to Testify at House Judiciary Subcommittee

Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google, tech critics and an ex-FTC commissioner will testify before the House Antitrust Subcommittee at 2 p.m. July 16 in 2141 Rayburn, Chairman David Cicilline, D-R.I., announced Tuesday. The hearing on online platforms and market power could have additional witnesses. Testimony is expected from Google Economic Policy Director Adam Cohen; Amazon Associate General Counsel-Litigation and Regulatory Legal Nate Sutton; Facebook Global Policy Development Head Matt Perault; Apple Vice President-Corporate Law and Chief Compliance Officer Kyle Andeer; Columbia Law School professor Tim Wu; Yale economics professor Fiona Scott Morton; Institute for Local Self-Reliance co-Director Stacy Mitchell; and ex-Commissioner Maureen Ohlhausen, now at Baker Botts. The hearing is a continuation of the House Judiciary Committee big tech investigation (see 1906110072).

urn:contentItem:5X3Y-FHW1-JBJN-M248-00000-00Google, Facebook, Amazon e Apple estão observação na Europa e nos Estados Unidos2019-09-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:19ZLexisNexisGoogle, Facebook, Amazon e Apple estão observação na Europa e nos Estados Unidos


Os gigantes da tecnologia levantam dúvidas para seu dominance da economia digital. Tradicionalmente a lupa da União Européia,a cerca nos Estados Unidos é agora também estreitando.
O debate está em cima da mesa. Os gigantes da tecnologia americana têm muito poder? Eles construíram seus impérios, violando a livre concorrência? Devemos levantar escrutínio sobre suas práticas comerciais? O poder dele deve ser limitado? A proteção da privacidade é estritamente regulada?


Enquanto empresas como o Google, Facebook e Amazon estão olhando para empresas como o Google, Facebook e Amazon na Europa, eles não encontraram quaisquer obstáculos em sua maneira de dominar a economia digital. No entanto, as vozes estão crescendo agora, pedindo não só maior vigilância, mas ações para limitar o seu poder e garantir um ambiente mais competitivo. Embora a tradição jurídica americana difere do Europeu, onde há uma cultura regulatória muito robusta, alguns escândalos recentes têm sido "tão importante que as autoridades americanas de supervisão não tiveram escolha senão enfrentar e abordar situações ", diz Alejandro Touriño, sócio-gerente da Ecja.
Amazon, Facebook e Google chamam de imposto de França contra...
Em julho, a Comissão Federal de comércio dos EUA (FTC) aprovou um recorde de $5000000000 multa contra o Facebook por violações de privacidade no caso da Cambridge Analytica. Pouco tempo depois, o departamento de Justiça anunciou uma investigação sem precedentes no país para determinar se gigantes digitais estão violando a livre concorrência. Em uma clara referência ao Google, Facebook e Amazon, você examinará as práticas das empresas que dominam a pesquisa na Internet, as mídias sociais e os serviços de varejo. A cruzada federal tem sido acompanhado por uma esmagadora maioria dos Estados, cujos advogados gerais se uniram para abordar uma investigação conjunta antitruste no Google e Facebook. Além disso, os legisladores têm procurado saber se a legislação vigente é adequada para garantir a livre concorrência na esfera digital durante meses.
Ainda mais delongas é o senador democrata Elizabeth Warren,que prometeu que, se ele atinge a casa branca, ele vai forçar Facebook, Amazon e Google para dividir. Warren acredita que eles têm estimado muito poder sobre a economia, sociedade e democracia, a concorrência varrida, usado dados de usuários privados para ganhar dinheiro, unevened as regras do jogo, prejudicou pequenas empresas e stied-em inovação.
Numa altura em que estas empresas alcançaram avaliações muito elevadas, tratam grandes quantidades de dados e têm um monopólio em determinados mercados, "parece obrigatório que os órgãos de fiscalização prestem especial atenção a eles, algo que não deve ser traduzido para perseguição, mas na observação de que a legalidade é cumprida ", diz Touriño, que se opõe a estabelecer medidas para retardar o seu crescimento. "Seria uma interferência significativa em sua independência e liberdade corporativa, o que não é justificado na minha opinião", diz ele. Um parecer compartilhado por Luis García, professor de finanças da ICADE Business School. "Certamente, é necessário mais escrutínio, o que não significa diretamente maior regulamentação, limitações ou controle", diz ele.
A "mudança vertiginosa e profunda" que a tecnologia trouxe em nossas vidas explica a "falta de reação" de alguns governos, especialmente nos Estados Unidos, onde prevalece a cultura empreendedora "desfalecer". E ele diz um exemplo: "se pudéssemos voltar para oúltima vez, estou convencido de que a compra de WhatsApp pelo Facebook seria olhado com outros olhos. "
O enorme poder que estes titãs têm acalorizado obriga as autoridades a não relaxarem a supervisão, pois o monopólio do acesso aos dados pode tornar-se uma barreira à livre concorrência. "A escalabilidade de seus modelos de negócios, com base em dados e informações, torna seu crescimento exponencial, o que aumenta o risco", diz Touriño. Garcia define um exemplo. Mais de 50% das pesquisas do Google terminam sem clicar. "O Google já não tem apenas um monopólio nas buscas, também está assumindo o monopólio do conteúdo", diz ele.
Este perito aponta para algumas áreas onde precisamos de estar vigilantes, especialmente para as relações intersectoriais. "A Amazon usa as informações que obtém de sua plataforma para competir como um fabricante com outros fabricantes? O Google usa informações de caminho em seus mapas para ver onde é mais rentável para colocar scooters? O Facebook escuta o WhatsApp ou usa informações de tráfego de dados entre países para lançar negócios financeiros? ", pergunta.
União Europeia
Como as preocupações crescem nos Estados Unidos, o cerco não é afrouxado na Europa. O Presidente eleito da Comissão Europeia, Ursula von der Leyen, da Alemanha, não mudará o curso do anterior governo comunitário. Margrethe Vestager repete-se como Comissário da concorrência e será também responsável pelos assuntos digitais.
Nos últimos anos, a Vestager tem sido o terror da Big Tech,que ele pesquisou – e multou – por suas práticas de negócios. O Google foi penalizado com 8.257.000 euros por abusar do seu domínio de mercado em várias áreas, enquanto a Apple teve de reembolsar a Irlanda 14.300.000.000 euros por beneficiar de auxílios estatais ilegais. O Facebook, a Amazon e a Apple também têm investigações antitruste contínuas. "Podemos precisar de regulamentação para garantir que essas plataformas usem seu poder de forma justa e não discriminatória", disse Vestager recentemente.
A tributação da grande tecnologia é outra prioridade para Ursula von der Leyen. A política é forte: "se no final de 2020 não houver uma solução global para um imposto digital justo, a UE deve agir por conta própria", diz ele.
Além disso, estes gigantes continuarão a estar a lupa de Bruxelas para as suas práticas de privacidade. Von der Leyen está convencido de que a inteligência artificial deve ser regulada. Ele prometeu que em seus primeiros 100 dias em propostas de escritório para a legislação será submetido a uma abordagem coordenada Europeia para as implicações éticas e humanas da inteligência artificial. Um regulamento que, sem dúvida, impactará as práticas desses gigantes.
Google: 8.257.000 multas na Europa
Bruxelas iniciou sua cruzada contra o Google em 2015, quando acusou a companhia de abusar de sua posição dominante para favorecer seu comparador. Desde então, acumulou multas de 8.257.000 euros por sua posição dominante no Android (a penalidade, de 4.343.000.000, é a maior da história da União Européia), por favorecer seu comparador em buscas e por usar práticas anticoncorrenciais publicidade de motores de pesquisa em websites de terceiros. Bruxelas também quer investigar o Google para empregos. Nos Estados Unidos, está no centro das atenções do departamento de Justiça e da Federal Trade Commission recentemente multado YouTube $170000000 para coletar informações de menores para fins publicitários.
Bruxelas abre uma investigação à Amazônia
O duplo papel da Amazon como distribuidor e mercado onde outras empresas vendem produtos levanta dúvidas. Neste verão, a União Europeia abriu uma investigaçãoAcredita que a empresa pode estar usando os dados dos comerciantes que vendem em sua plataforma para favorecer o seu próprio negócio de comércio eletrônico. Por exemplo, um estudo publicado pela Universidade de Harvard descobriu que a Amazon usa esses dados para identificar os sucessos de vendas dessas empresas e ser capaz de liberar sua própria versão, que então aparece de forma relevante em pesquisas de produtos na plataforma. A empresa também está agora na mira das autoridades de concorrência dos EUA.
Facebook após o caso de Cambridge Analytica
A Comissão Federal de comércio dos EUA (FTC) neste verão aprovou um recorde $5000000000 multa contra o Facebook para violações de privacidade. O sanção fecha o litígio que abriu em 2018 sobre o roubo de milhões de dados do usuário pela consultoria britânica Cambridge Analytica. Na Europa, a autoridade antitruste alemã governou em fevereiro que o Facebook está abusando de sua posição dominante no mercado, por isso vai impor limitações na rede social para coletar e usar dados de seus usuários coletados de outras de suas plataformas, como WhatsApp ou Instagram. Além disso, a Comissão Europeia enviou um questionário ao Facebook pedindo à rede social perguntas "específicas" sobre a sua criptomoeda libra com o objectivo de ter uma "imagem mais completa" da iniciativa antes de tomar uma decisão sobre o seu lançamento União Europeia. O Facebook também está na mira das autoridades americanas, que discutirão se ele se envolveu em práticas anticompetitivas.
Apple: vantagens fiscais ilegais
A Europa quer analisar se a Apple se envolveu em práticas anticoncorrenciais em seu serviço de aplicativo, após o serviço de streaming de música Spotify processou multinacional de tecnologia dos EUA para Bruxelas para Bruxelas concorrência desleal, uma vez que considera que as condições da sua loja "apps" favorecem o seu serviço sobre os da concorrência. Até à data, o grande encontro entre a UE e a Apple foi tributado. A empresa teve de reembolsar a Irlanda 14.300.000.000 euros (13.100.000.000 impostos não recolhidos mais juros) depois de a Comissão Europeia ter decidido que tinha recebido vantagens fiscais ilegais, uma decisão apelada pela Apple e pela Irlanda.

value.Title: Google, Facebook, Amazon: Warren's toothless break-up plan ignores real Big Tech threats

Extracts.SummaryText: Second, Warren wants to appoint "regulators committed to reversing illegal and anti-competitive tech mergers." But we already have such regulators — antitrust officials at both the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice. They might have been asleep at the wheel when it comes to Big Tech, but they seem to be waking up. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VPJ-GDX1-DXVP-V1B7-00000-00Google, Facebook, Amazon: Warren's toothless break-up plan ignores real Big Tech threats2019-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:55:19ZLexisNexisUSA TODAYGoogle, Facebook, Amazon: Warren's toothless break-up plan ignores real Big Tech threatsRobert Epstein

Presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren recently called for breaking up Facebook, Google, and Amazon, claiming in her detailed proposal that they have too much power and stifle competition and innovation. She has also said, separately, that Apple should be dismembered as well. The trouble is, her plan doesn't address the real dangers posed by Big Tech.

These companies need to be taken down, Warren says, because they buy up possible competitors (consider Facebook's 2012 purchase of Instagram, a photo-sharing application) and, in some cases, because they crush small businesses by directly competing with those businesses on their platforms (for example, when Amazon offers its own branded version of a product another company is selling on Amazon).

Her solutions? First, pass legislation that would label any large tech company a "platform utility" that would be "prohibited from owning … any participants on that platform." This means Amazon couldn't sell its own branded widgets on Amazon and that Google couldn't set up its own comparison shopping service while demoting competing shopping services in its search results. In 2017, Google was fined $2.7 billion by the EU for doing exactly that.

Read more commentary:

Facebook, YouTube and social media are failing society. Pull their ads until they change.

I loved Facebook. After 12 years of daily use, here's why I'm unfriending it for good.

Not just conservatives: Google and Big Tech can shift millions of votes in any direction

Second, Warren wants to appoint "regulators committed to reversing illegal and anti-competitive tech mergers." But we already have such regulators — antitrust officials at both the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice. They might have been asleep at the wheel when it comes to Big Tech, but they seem to be waking up. In late February, the FTC announced that it had formed a task force to scrutinize Big Tech, and, yes, it will also look specifically at past acquisitions and mergers.

That's all she wrote, which is far from enough. Warren's first mistake was to throw Amazon and Apple into the same pot with Google and Facebook. Apple sells actual projects that it manufactures, and Amazon is a highly efficient distributor of actual goods — a digital version of Walmart. Meanwhile, Walmart is gearing up at this very moment to challenge Amazon in cyberspace. Unlike monopolies that raise prices at will (think: modern pharmaceutical companies), Amazon, like Walmart, has been lowering prices, which makes it a questionable candidate for antitrust actions.

Warren recklessly lumps companies together

Other than being big and techie, Google and Facebook are nothing like Amazon and Apple. While Amazon, Walmart, Microsoft and Apple sell actual products, Google and Facebook do something very different. They sell you, me and our kids to advertisers, while pretending to be benign providers of an endless array of "free" services — services that we pay for with our data and our freedom. Google, Facebook and the growing phalanx of companies that are emulating them rely on a surveillance business model that Apple's Tim Cook has called "creepy" and that retired Harvard professor Shoshana Zuboff expertly exposes in a new book.

Google and Facebook pose three grave threats to democracy and human freedom: fine-grained surveillance of billions of people around the world, the ability to determine what information those people see and don't see (the censorship problem), and the ability to manipulate people's thinking, behavior and votes without them knowing they're being influenced. The latter problem, which I've been studying through both monitoring projects and controlled experiments for more than six years, troubles me most, but all three of these problems are serious. I'm now studying and quantifying seven different methods these companies can use to shift votes and opinions on a massive scale, and I'm aware of other subtle manipulations that still need to be studied.

Warren's proposal doesn't even begin to address these threats. Her proposal is so far off the mark, in fact, that it makes me wonder whether she's actually trying to help these companies rather than contain them. Google is one of her largest donors, and she has also received substantial donations from employees at three of the companies she wants to regulate. People tend not to bite the hand that feeds them.

More unchecked power than any dictator

Either Warren is playing a subtle game, or she just doesn't get it. She even reassures us that after her new laws and regulations have cleaned up these companies a bit, the surveillance will continue unabated: "You'll still be able to go on Google and search like you do today," she says. "You'll still be able to go on Facebook and see how your old friend from school is doing."

She implicitly recognizes but doesn't address the real problem: You can't disempower Google's core monopoly because you can't dismember its search engine. If you did, each of the remnants of that search engine would give you inferior results. And you also can't disempower Facebook's core monopoly because you can't dismember Facebook's social network platform. Doing so would be like erecting an über version of the Berlin Wall, splitting millions of families apart irreparably.

Even if Gmail, Chrome, and Android were spun off from Google, and even if Instagram and WhatsApp were spun off from Facebook, the ravenous bellies of the beasts — Google's search engine and Facebook's social network platform — would continue to give these companies unchecked power the likes of which no dictator on earth has ever had.

Can anything be done to curtail such power? Yes, and many well-informed people are working on the problem — among them Sir Tim Berners-Lee, the inventor of the World Wide Web; Roger McNamee, an early investor in both Google and Facebook; and Tristan Harris, a former "design ethicist" at Google. As for Warren, her proposal is not only toothless, it also suggests that she doesn't understand the nature of the threat we face.

Robert Epstein, a former editor-in-chief of Psychology Today, is senior research psychologist at the American Institute for Behavioral Research and Technology. The author of 15 books and more than 300 articles, he is working on a book called "How Google and Facebook Ate Your Brain, and How You Can Get a New One." Follow him on Twitter: @DrREpstein

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Google, Facebook, Amazon: Warren's toothless break-up plan ignores real Big Tech threats
